body.head: Private Stewart C. Glover
body.p: Private Stewart C. Glover Co. E 5 Wis. Vols. Wounded, mortally, in battle of the Wilderness Va 5 May 64. Died 21 May '64. Aged about 20 years. The fighting had ceased for the day and the General com'd'ing the Brigade rode by and called for Volunteers to bring in the wounded. Barry Glover was among the first and when in the act of pulling in towards our lines a wounded Serg't was shot in the knee by a rebel Sharpshooter. Amputation and death was the result. He was in Hancock's Corps. This was the 1st day's fighting. He resided with his father Mr John Glover, an aged and feeble man, in Batavia Genesee Co New York, and while at school in Wisconsin enrolled himself in the army of the union. On the day of his death he wrote the following was in he kept a littlelittleblank memoir under book like so many of the soldiers in his diary. "Today the Dr says I must die.
body.ab: I supp It is now All is now over with me. Alas, so young to die!
R.H. Foote Room No 4 Penny Ms Gui'o
He had served nearly 3 years and would have been entitled to discharge in a few days.
He wrote in his Diary—"Dear brother Thomas, I have been brave but wicked pray for me—"
